results.pure_llm_reasoning: Meets DSM-5-TR criteria for Major Depressive Disorder: patient has >5 depressive symptoms (depressed mood, markedly diminished interest, weight loss/decreased appetite, insomnia, psychomotor retardation, fatigue, feelings of worthlessness, diminished concentration, recurrent thoughts of death) present most of each day for ~3 weeks (exceeds 2-week threshold), causing functional impairment and not better explained by substance/medical condition. Other diagnoses not met: GAD requires excessive worry ≥6 months (duration too short); ADHD and ASD require lifelong/childhood onset and characteristic developmental history (absent); PTSD criteria (trauma exposure, intrusion/avoidance/arousal cluster for ≥1 month) are not met.

Meets DSM-5-TR criteria for Generalized Anxiety Disorder: >6 months of pervasive, excessive worry about multiple domains that is difficult to control, with ≥3 associated symptoms (restlessness, fatigue, impaired concentration, irritability, muscle tension, sleep disturbance) and clear functional impairment. Does not meet MDD (insufficient depressive symptoms/anhedonia and duration/signature), ADHD (no childhood-onset history and symptoms better explained by anxiety), PTSD (no qualifying traumatic exposure or symptoms), or ASD (no lifelong developmental social-communication or restrictive/repetitive symptom history).

Meets DSM-5-TR criteria for ADHD: numerous inattentive symptoms (careless errors, seeming not to listen, poor organization/time management, avoidance of sustained mental effort, frequently losing items, distractibility) and multiple hyperactive/impulsive symptoms (leaving seat, restlessness, blurting out, difficulty waiting/interruption). Symptoms began in childhood (~age 5), have been present for >6 months, occur in work/meeting settings with clear occupational impairment. Other disorders not met: MDD — no persistent depressed mood or anhedonia and insufficient depressive symptom criteria; GAD — no pervasive excessive worry for ≥6 months or associated anxiety symptoms; PTSD — no traumatic exposure or PTSD symptom cluster; ASD — no lifelong core social-communication deficits or restricted/repetitive patterns described.

Acute Stress Disorder: Patient had in-person witnessing of a multi-vehicle collision and onset of symptoms immediately after the event with current symptoms present for ~1 month. She reports dissociative reactions/flashback‑like episodes (feels like she is back there), avoidance of external reminders (avoids the stretch of road, avoids conversations about crashes, asks others to drive), persistent negative mood/inability to feel pleasure, and arousal symptoms (irritability, sleep difficulty, concentration problems) with functional impairment — consistent with ASD within the first month after trauma. Major Depressive Disorder (MDD): Over the past month she endorses depressed/negative mood, markedly diminished interest/pleasure, insomnia, fatigue/'wiped out', excessive guilt/shame, and impaired concentration with occupational and social dysfunction — meeting criteria for a major depressive episode (>2 weeks, ≥5 symptoms). Excluded: GAD (symptoms <6 months, worry not generalized), ADHD (no childhood history, recent onset of concentration problems), PTSD (requires symptoms persisting >1 month and more consistent/recurrent intrusive phenomena; timeframe and some PTSD-specific intrusion criteria not clearly met).

Meets DSM-5-TR preschool PTSD criteria: clear traumatic exposure (witnessed caregivers hurt), multiple intrusion/re-experiencing symptoms (repetitive reenactment play, repetitive phrases, distressing dreams), avoidance/marked change in behavior (refusal to enter car/backyard, constricted play), negative alterations and arousal/reactivity (increased clinginess, exaggerated startle, hypervigilance, intense temper outbursts, sleep disturbance, toileting regression), duration ~1 month and causing functional impairment. MDD not met (insufficient number/duration of depressive symptoms and no suicidality); GAD not met (symptoms are trauma-related and duration <6 months); ADHD not met (attention/hyperactivity are situational, recent onset after trauma, not pervasive/persistent from early development); ASD not met (developmental history and prior social-communication skills are age-appropriate and symptoms are trauma-onset rather than lifelong).

Meets DSM-5-TR criteria for Autism Spectrum Disorder: lifelong (since ~age 7) persistent deficits in social-emotional reciprocity (one-sided conversations, limited sharing of feelings, failure to ask about others), deficits in nonverbal communicative behaviors and social reciprocity (limited spontaneous gestures, constricted affect, limited insight into social impact), and restricted, repetitive patterns of behavior, interests, and activities (intense narrow interests in clocks/schedules, repetitive finger flicking, lining up objects, distress at changes, sensory hypersensitivities). Symptoms began in early development, are pervasive and cause functional/social impairment. Criteria for MDD, GAD, ADHD, and PTSD are not met based on the history (no depressive syndrome of ≥2 weeks with requisite symptoms, no ≥6 months of excessive generalized worry, no core ADHD inattentive/hyperactive symptom cluster, and no trauma history or PTSD symptom cluster).

Meets DSM-5-TR criteria for Major Depressive Disorder: patient has ≥5 symptoms (markedly diminished interest, fatigue/low energy, feelings of worthlessness/excessive guilt, diminished concentration/indecisiveness, recurrent thoughts of death) present for ~3 weeks (≥2 weeks), with functional impairment and no medical/substance explanation. Other disorders not met: GAD — insufficient duration and lack of pervasive excessive worry; ADHD — no history of childhood-onset, symptoms are recent and situational; PTSD — no qualifying traumatic exposure or symptom cluster; ASD — no developmental history or pervasive social-communication/restricted-repetitive symptoms.

Meets DSM-5-TR GAD criteria: >6 months of excessive anxiety/worry most days about multiple domains, difficulty controlling worry, and ≥3 associated symptoms (restlessness, fatigue, difficulty concentrating, irritability, muscle tension, sleep disturbance) with functional impairment at work and home. No evidence of trauma (rules out PTSD), no lifelong childhood history of inattention/hyperactivity (not consistent with ADHD), insufficient depressive symptoms for MDD, and no features of ASD.

Meets DSM-5-TR criteria for ADHD, combined presentation: history of attentional symptoms beginning ~age 9 (before age 12), current persistent inattention (mind wandering, not listening, losing items, forgetfulness, failure to follow through) and hyperactive-impulsive features (leaving seat, restlessness, talking a lot, blurting/interruption) across settings with clear functional impairment at work and home for months. Symptoms are not better accounted for by MDD, GAD, PTSD, or ASD (no depressive syndrome, no pervasive excessive worry, no trauma exposure, no developmental social-communication deficits).

Meets criteria for Acute Stress Disorder: recent direct exposure (witnessed violent event) with onset ~1 month ago (within 3 days–1 month window), and multiple ASD symptom clusters present — dissociative amnesia (gap in memory), avoidance of thoughts/talking, persistent negative mood (fear, guilt, anger), physiological reactivity to cues, sleep disturbance, irritability/reckless behavior, and concentration problems causing distress/impairment. Does not meet PTSD (insufficient duration; PTSD requires symptoms >1 month). Does not meet MDD (insufficient number/duration of depressive symptoms), GAD (lack of >6 months of pervasive worry), or ADHD (no childhood history or core inattentive/hyperactive symptoms consistent with DSM-5-TR).

Meets DSM-5-TR PTSD (preschool subtype) criteria: direct exposure to traumatic event (witnessed house fire and mother injured); persistent intrusion symptoms (repetitive reenactment in play, nightmares, dissociative 'stare' episodes resembling flashbacks); avoidance (refusal to enter bedroom, avoidance of location on street); negative alterations/behavioral changes (withdrawal, increased clinginess, decreased interest in play, appetite/sleep disturbance, new daytime toileting accident); marked arousal (exaggerated startle, sleep disturbance, irritability). Symptoms have been present ~1 month and cause functional impairment. Other diagnoses not met: MDD — insufficient number and pattern of depressive symptoms; GAD — lacks >6 months of pervasive excessive worry; ADHD — no longstanding, pervasive attention/hyperactivity symptoms prior to 12 years and <6 months; ASD — developmental history and symptom onset are inconsistent with lifelong neurodevelopmental pattern.

Meets DSM-5-TR criteria for Autism Spectrum Disorder: persistent deficits in social communication/interaction (one-sided conversations, limited emotional reciprocity, poor nonverbal modulation, difficulty making friends) and restricted/repetitive patterns (stereotyped movements, insistence on sameness with marked distress when routines change, highly restricted interests, sensory hyper‑reactivity). Symptoms began in childhood (~age 10), cause current functional impairment at work and in relationships, and are not better explained by another listed disorder. MDD not supported (no pervasive depressed mood or anhedonia), GAD lacks broad uncontrollable worry across multiple domains, ADHD lacks core inattentive/hyperactive symptoms, and PTSD lacks trauma exposure and intrusion/avoidance symptoms.

Meets DSM-5-TR criteria for Major Depressive Disorder: patient has depressed mood plus at least four additional symptoms (unintentional weight loss/decreased appetite, insomnia/changes in sleep, psychomotor retardation/occasional agitation, recurrent thoughts of death/passive suicidal ideation) present nearly every day for ~3 weeks (>2 weeks) with functional slowing and distress. Other diagnoses not met: GAD requires ≥6 months of excessive worry (here ~3 weeks); ADHD requires childhood-onset, persistent symptoms ≥6 months and pervasive impairments (not present); PTSD requires qualifying traumatic exposure and characteristic intrusion/avoidance/alterations (not reported); ASD requires lifelong developmental history of social-communication deficits and restricted/repetitive behaviors (not present).

Does not meet DSM-5-TR criteria for any listed disorder. GAD: current presentation includes excessive, hard-to-control worry about multiple domains, but duration is ~5 months (DSM-5-TR requires ≥6 months) and the patient does not endorse ≥3 associated symptoms (restlessness, fatigue, difficulty concentrating, irritability, muscle tension, sleep disturbance), so full GAD criteria are not met. MDD: no pervasive depressed mood, anhedonia, or sufficient depressive symptoms for ≥2 weeks. ADHD: no history of childhood-onset persistent inattention/hyperactivity and current exam shows intact attention. PTSD: no qualifying traumatic exposure or trauma symptoms. ASD: no developmental history or persistent social/communication deficits or restricted/repetitive behaviors reported.

Meets DSM-5-TR criteria for ADHD, combined presentation: multiple inattentive (careless errors, difficulty sustaining attention, disorganization, losing things, forgetfulness) and hyperactive-impulsive symptoms (motor restlessness, leaves seat, talks/interrupts, blurts answers) present since ~age 10 (before age 12), ongoing >6 months, observed in multiple settings (work/meetings, home), and causing occupational impairment. Symptoms are not better accounted for by substance use or medical condition. Does not meet criteria for MDD (no persistent depressed mood or required symptom cluster), GAD (no pervasive excessive worry across domains), PTSD (no trauma history), or ASD (no clear lifelong social-communication deficits or restricted/repetitive behaviors documented).

Meets DSM-5-TR criteria for PTSD: clear Criterion A trauma exposure (directly exposed, witnessed multiple deaths/injuries, learned of death of close coworker). Intrusive symptoms (recurrent involuntary images, nightmares, dissociative flashback episodes), persistent avoidance of reminders (avoids plant, coworkers, cancels family visits), negative alterations in cognition/mood (self-blame, shame, constricted affect), marked alterations in arousal/reactivity (hypervigilance, exaggerated startle, irritability/angry outbursts, reckless driving, concentration/sleep disturbance) with functional impairment. Symptoms began ≈1 month after the event and are present beyond the acute period, consistent with PTSD rather than Acute Stress Disorder. Does not meet criteria for MDD (insufficient depressive symptom cluster and duration), GAD (absence of ≥6 months of pervasive excessive worry), or ADHD (no childhood history or criteria met).

Meets DSM-5-TR Preschool/Young Child PTSD criteria: direct exposure to a violent home incident (Criterion A); intrusive symptoms (repetitive trauma-themed play, nightmares, screaming/night terrors, dissociative-like freezing; Criterion B); avoidance of reminders (refusal to approach front door or go to park) and marked clinginess (Criterion C: avoidance/negative alterations as expressed in young children); arousal/reactivity (exaggerated startle, sleep disturbance/night wakings, irritability/tantrums, concentration difficulties; Criterion D); duration ≈1 month (meets the ≥1 month requirement) with clear functional impairment. Does not meet criteria for MDD (insufficient number/duration of depressive symptoms), GAD (worry not generalized or ≥6 months), ADHD (insufficient pervasive, long-standing inattention/hyperactivity symptoms present before age 12 and across settings), or ASD (no evidence of pervasive, early-onset social-communication deficits or lifelong restrictive/repetitive developmental pattern).

Meets DSM-5-TR criteria for Autism Spectrum Disorder: lifelong (symptoms noted since ~age 11) persistent deficits in social-emotional reciprocity (limited back-and-forth, reduced sharing of emotion), deficits in nonverbal communicative behaviors (avoids eye contact, limited gestures, constricted affect), and restricted, repetitive patterns of behavior/interests (echolalia, lining up objects, strict routines, intense special interests, sensory sensitivities) causing social/occupational impairment. Presentation is not consistent with MDD, GAD, ADHD, or PTSD given absence of core mood symptoms, pervasive excessive worry, cardinal attention/hyperactivity symptoms, or trauma-related symptoms.

Meets DSM-5-TR criteria for Major Depressive Disorder: ≥5 depressive symptoms present nearly every day for >2 weeks (3 weeks here) with depressed mood, marked loss of interest, psychomotor retardation, pervasive worthlessness/excessive guilt, and recurrent thoughts of death/passive suicidal ideation; symptoms cause functional change and are not better explained by substances or a medical condition. Does not meet GAD (insufficient duration — symptoms <6 months — and lacks core anxiety/worry features), ADHD (no lifelong history or core inattention/hyperactivity symptoms), PTSD (no qualifying traumatic exposure or symptom cluster), or ASD (no developmental history of social-communication deficits or restrictive/repetitive behaviors).

MDD: Patient has ≥6 months of depressed mood and anhedonia with ≥5 symptoms consistent with DSM-5-TR (weight loss/decreased appetite, insomnia/early awakening, psychomotor slowing, fatigue, feelings of worthlessness/guilt, impaired concentration, recurrent thoughts of death/passive SI), causing functional impairment, not better explained by medical/substance use and no history of mania/hypomania. GAD: Excessive worry more days than not for ≥6 months about multiple domains (work, family), difficulty controlling worry, and ≥3 associated symptoms (restlessness, easy fatigability, difficulty concentrating/mind going blank, irritability, muscle tension, sleep disturbance) with functional impairment. ADHD: Not met — no history of pervasive attentional/hyperactivity symptoms dating back to childhood. PTSD: Not met — no reported qualifying trauma or characteristic PTSD symptom cluster. ASD: Not met — no lifelong developmental/social-communication history supporting autism spectrum disorder.

The presentation is most consistent with ADHD-like symptoms (multiple inattentive and hyperactive-impulsive symptoms, impairment at work and in interactions, symptoms across settings). However, by DSM-5-TR strict criteria ADHD requires several symptoms present prior to age 12 and symptoms persisting for at least 6 months; the record states onset around age 24 and current pattern ~5 months (and childhood history is not documented), so full DSM-5-TR ADHD criteria are not met based on available information. MDD is not met (no depressed mood, anhedonia, suicidal ideation, or sufficient constellation of 5+ symptoms for 2 weeks). GAD is not met (no ≥6 months of pervasive excessive worry or the required symptom pattern). PTSD is not met (no qualifying trauma exposure). ASD is not met (no early-developmental social-communication deficits or restricted/repetitive behaviors reported). Recommend collation of childhood developmental history and symptom duration to reassess for ADHD; consider functional assessment and rule out substance/medical contributors.

Meets DSM-5-TR criteria for Acute Stress Disorder: recent exposure (witnessed violent event), multiple symptoms across required domains within the first month—intrusion (distressing dreams, replaying scene), negative mood (reduced ability to experience positive emotions), dissociative-feeling detached, avoidance of external reminders (intersection/store, conversations), and arousal (insomnia, irritability/anger outburst, concentration difficulties) with clinically significant distress/impairment. Does not meet PTSD (symptoms present ~4 weeks; PTSD requires duration >1 month). Does not meet criteria for MDD (insufficient number/severity/duration of depressive symptoms), GAD (duration, pervasive worry and criteria not met), or ADHD (onset/history inconsistent with ADHD).

Does not meet full DSM-5-TR criteria for any listed disorder. PTSD: exposure and several PTSD-type symptoms are present (repetitive traumatic play, heightened startle/hyperarousal, sleep disturbance, regression, clinginess), but duration is ~3 weeks (DSM-5-TR requires ≥1 month) and some required symptom clusters/avoidance criteria are not clearly met → does not meet full PTSD. MDD: insufficient number/type of depressive symptoms. GAD: symptomalogy and duration (<6 months) insufficient. ADHD: no persistent pattern of inattention/hyperactivity across settings for ≥6 months. ASD: social-communication and longstanding repetitive/restricted behavior prior to trauma are not present; recent repetitive play appears trauma-related. Clinical impression: acute stress reaction/trauma-related distress with provisional risk for PTSD if symptoms persist beyond 1 month.

Meets DSM-5-TR criteria for Autism Spectrum Disorder: persistent deficits in social communication/interaction (poor eye contact, limited gestures, reduced back-and-forth conversation, diminished social-emotional reciprocity) and restricted/repetitive patterns of behavior and interests (repetitive verbalizations/echolalia, motor mannerisms, intense narrow interest in vintage watches). Symptoms are longstanding from adolescence with recent functional impact at work. Does not meet criteria for MDD (no depressed mood, anhedonia, or other threshold symptoms), GAD (no ≥6 months of excessive worry across domains), ADHD (no clear pervasive inattention/hyperactivity since childhood), or PTSD (no qualifying traumatic exposure or symptom cluster).

Meets DSM-5-TR criteria for Major Depressive Disorder: ≥5 depressive symptoms present nearly every day (depressed mood, marked anhedonia, significant weight loss/decreased appetite, insomnia with early morning awakening, psychomotor retardation, fatigue, diminished concentration/indecisiveness, feelings of worthlessness, recurrent thoughts of death) for >2 weeks (3 weeks total) with significant functional impairment after job loss. Symptoms are not better explained by substances or a medical condition and there is no history of manic/hypomanic episodes. GAD not met (worry <6 months); ADHD not supported (no childhood history, symptoms appear secondary to mood); PTSD not met (no qualifying trauma or symptom cluster); ASD not met (no developmental history or core social/communication deficits).

Meets DSM-5-TR criteria for Generalized Anxiety Disorder: >6 months of excessive, difficult-to-control worry about multiple domains (work, finances, family), associated clinically significant impairment (irritability/snaping at coworkers, interpersonal strain), and at least two associated symptoms documented (irritability and sleep disturbance; mild observed restlessness adds support). Symptoms are not better explained by substance, medical condition, or another mental disorder. Does not meet criteria for MDD (no persistent depressed mood or core vegetative symptoms), ADHD (no longstanding childhood inattention/hyperactivity and recent onset), PTSD (no qualifying trauma), or ASD (no developmental history of social-communication deficits or restricted/repetitive patterns).

Meets DSM-5-TR criteria for ADHD (combined presentation): multiple inattentive (careless mistakes, difficulty organizing, losing items, distractibility, forgetfulness) and hyperactive-impulsive symptoms (fidgeting, leaving desk, feeling 'on the go', rapid/interrupting speech, blurting, difficulty waiting) present for >6 months, symptoms reported since ~age 5 (onset before age 12), present in work and interpersonal settings, and causing clear impairment at work. Criteria for MDD not met (no persistent depressed mood or ≥5 SIGECAPS for 2 weeks); GAD not met (no pervasive excessive worry for ≥6 months across domains); PTSD not met (no trauma exposure or symptoms); ASD not met (no persistent social-communication deficits or restricted/repetitive behavior reported).

Meets DSM-5-TR PTSD criteria: Criterion A — repeated work-related exposure to aversive details as a first responder; Criterion B — recurrent intrusive images/memories; Criterion C — active avoidance of external reminders; Criterion D — negative alterations in cognitions/mood including persistent self- and other-blaming and inability to recall an important aspect of events (dissociative amnesia); Criterion E — marked alterations in arousal/reactivity (irritability/angry outbursts, difficulty concentrating). Duration is approximately 1 month (consistent with the >1 month requirement in typical clinical practice). Does not meet criteria for ASD (insufficient number of required symptoms in the 3‑day to 1‑month window), MDD (insufficient depressive symptom count/duration), GAD (duration <6 months and worry is event-specific), or ADHD (no lifelong pattern or childhood history).

Presentation best fits PTSD (preschool subtype) per DSM-5-TR: exposure via learning of a caregiver’s distressing event, presence of intrusion (recurrent nightmares), trauma-themed/repetitive play (re-enactment), marked clinginess/separation distress and social withdrawal, hyperarousal (exaggerated startle, irritability/outbursts), sleep disturbance and regression (toileting). Symptoms cause impairment and have been present for approximately one month (meets the >1 month requirement). Criteria for MDD, GAD, ADHD, and ASD are not met: MDD lacks sufficient number/duration of depressive symptoms; GAD and ADHD require symptoms present for ≥6 months and a broader/persistent symptom set across settings; ASD requires early, pervasive social-communication deficits and lifelong pattern not present here.

Meets DSM-5-TR criteria for Autism Spectrum Disorder: lifelong (since early childhood) deficits in social communication and social reciprocity (limited eye contact, reduced gestures, one‑word answers, poor recognition of social impact) plus restricted, repetitive patterns of behavior/interests (lining pens, repeating phrases, insistence on sameness after train delay, intense restricted interest in watches). Symptoms cause clinically significant impairment and began in early development. Does not meet criteria for MDD (no persistent depressed mood or other depressive symptoms), GAD (no >6 months of pervasive excessive worry), ADHD (no clear pattern of inattention/hyperactivity-impulsivity), or PTSD (no trauma history or trauma-related symptoms).

Meets DSM-5-TR criteria for Major Depressive Disorder: patient has ≥5 core symptoms (depressed mood, anhedonia, ~6% weight loss/decreased appetite, insomnia/early morning awakening, psychomotor retardation, fatigue, excessive worthlessness/guilt, impaired concentration, recurrent thoughts of death) present for 3 weeks (>2 weeks) with significant functional impairment and no clear medical/substance cause; no history of mania/hypomania. Does not meet GAD (no ≥6 months of excessive/worry and core anxiety features), does not meet ADHD (no childhood history or long-standing attention symptoms), does not meet PTSD (no qualifying traumatic exposure or PTSD symptom cluster), and does not meet ASD (no early developmental/social-communication history).

PTSD: Meets DSM-5-TR criteria — direct exposure to a traumatic event (daughter's death in multi-vehicle collision), persistent intrusive memories/flashbacks and nightmares, dissociative re-experiencing, avoidance of reminders (highway, ride-alongs), marked arousal/reactivity (startle, hypervigilance, irritability, sleep disturbance, concentration problems), duration >1 month (≈6 months), and clinically significant distress/impairment. GAD: Meets DSM-5-TR criteria — excessive, difficult-to-control worry about multiple domains most days for ≈6 months, with ≥3 associated symptoms (restlessness, fatigue, irritability/angry outbursts, muscle tension, sleep disturbance, impaired concentration), and causing distress/impairment; not better explained by substances or a medical condition. MDD: Not met — insufficient depressive symptoms/duration (no persistent depressed mood or anhedonia and fewer than required symptoms). ADHD: Not met — no childhood onset history or longstanding pervasive symptoms. ASD: Not met — symptoms have persisted well beyond the 3–30 day window required for acute stress disorder.

Does not meet DSM-5-TR criteria for the listed disorders: ADHD — current symptoms (inattention, restlessness, impulsivity across work and daily life) are consistent with adult ADHD but DSM-5-TR requires several symptoms present before age 12; history indicates onset ~age 24 and no childhood symptoms documented, so full ADHD criteria are not met. MDD — no persistent depressed mood or anhedonia, insufficient number/duration of SIGECAPS symptoms to meet major depressive episode. GAD — restlessness and concentration problems present but no evidence of excessive, uncontrollable worry across domains for ≥6 months. PTSD — no qualifying trauma exposure or intrusive/avoidance symptoms reported. ASD — no early developmental history of social-communication deficits or restricted/repetitive behavior described. Therefore none of the five disorders meet full DSM-5-TR criteria based on available information.

Meets DSM-5-TR PTSD criteria: direct exposure to traumatic assault (Criterion A); recurrent intrusive memories (B); avoidance of internal reminders (trying not to think/talk) (C); persistent negative cognitions/self-blame (D); arousal/reactivity symptoms including sleep disturbance, irritability/on-edge, reckless driving and substance use (E); duration >1 month with functional impairment. Does not meet ASD (symptoms persist beyond 1 month), insufficient/insubstantial symptom pattern or duration for MDD or GAD, and no evidence/history to support ADHD.

Meets DSM-5-TR PTSD (preschool) features: A) exposure by learning that a caregiver (father) was injured; B) intrusion manifested as repetitive reenactment play about the injury and statements like "it's happening again"; C) avoidance/alterations — refusal to enter garage and avoidant behavior for places reminding him of the event, sleep disturbance and nightmares; D) arousal/reactivity — exaggerated startle, increased clinginess, tantrums, concentration problems, sleep disturbance; duration ~1 month with clear functional impairment. Does not meet MDD (insufficient number of depressive symptoms), GAD (duration/criteria not met), ADHD (insufficient duration and cross-situational history of inattention/hyperactivity), or ASD (no persistent deficits in social communication or early developmental history supporting autism).

Meets DSM-5-TR criteria for Autism Spectrum Disorder: lifelong (since ~age 5) persistent deficits in social communication/interaction (limited initiation, reduced reciprocal conversation, atypical eye contact, literal speech/echolalia, difficulty reading faces) plus restricted, repetitive patterns of behavior and interests (stereotyped motor movements, insistence on sameness, narrowly circumscribed interests, sensory hypersensitivities/hyposensitivities). Symptoms cause clinically significant impairment in social/occupational functioning. Does not meet criteria for MDD (insufficient depressive symptoms), GAD (worry not generalized and <6 months), ADHD (insufficient core inattention/hyperactivity criteria across settings), or PTSD (no trauma exposure).

Does not meet full DSM-5-TR criteria for any listed disorder. Major depressive disorder: patient has diminished interest, significant weight loss, impaired concentration/indecisiveness, and recurrent thoughts of death/passive SI (4 core symptoms), but DSM-5-TR requires ≥5 symptoms present during the same 2-week period; depressed mood and other symptoms (sleep, fatigue, psychomotor change, worthlessness) are denied, and decreased interest appears to have been present only ~1 week. Generalized anxiety disorder: lacks excessive worry across multiple domains and the required ≥6 months duration. ADHD: adult diagnosis requires childhood-onset symptoms and a longstanding pattern across settings, which is not reported. PTSD: no qualifying traumatic exposure or symptom cluster. Autism spectrum disorder: no developmental history or characteristic social-communication/restricted-behavior symptoms documented. Clinical concern: patient has passive suicidal ideation and functional impairment and warrants follow-up and safety assessment.

Patient has excessive, difficult-to-control worry focused on work with associated functional interference, consistent with GAD features. However DSM-5-TR GAD criteria are not fully met: symptoms are reported for approximately 5 months (DSM requires ≥6 months) and the patient endorses fewer than the required three associated symptoms (denies restlessness, fatigue, difficulty concentrating, irritability, muscle tension, or sleep disturbance). MDD, ADHD, PTSD, and ASD are not met based on the history and exam (no core depressive syndrome, no childhood-onset or persistent attentional/hyperactive symptoms, no trauma exposure or PTSD symptom cluster, and no lifelong social-communication or restrictive/repetitive features of ASD). Recommend re-evaluation if symptoms persist to 6 months or worsen.

Meets DSM-5-TR criteria for ADHD, combined presentation: history of symptoms beginning in childhood (~age 4), multiple inattentive symptoms (careless errors, difficulty sustaining attention, disorganization, avoidance of sustained mental effort, losing items, forgetfulness) and hyperactive-impulsive symptoms (fidgeting, leaving seat, excessive talking, blurting/interrupting) with persistence for >6 months, impairment at work, and symptoms present in multiple settings. MDD, GAD, PTSD, and ASD are not supported by the history/exam (no pervasive depressed mood/anhedonia or other MDD criteria; no excessive uncontrollable worry meeting GAD criteria; no trauma- or PTSD-related symptoms; no early and pervasive social-communication deficits or restricted/repetitive behaviors consistent with ASD).

Meets DSM-5-TR PTSD: Criterion A (directly experienced/witnessed deadly injury and repeated exposure), B intrusion symptoms (recurrent intrusive images, nightmares, dissociative re-experiencing), C avoidance (avoids overpass, news, coworkers), D negative alterations (guilt, persistent negative beliefs, memory gap, emotional numbing/withdrawal), E arousal/reactivity (irritability/anger, hypervigilance, exaggerated startle, impaired concentration, sleep disturbance), F duration >1 month, and G clinically significant distress/impairment (stopped volunteering, relationship and daily functioning impacts). Does not meet MDD (insufficient depressive symptom count/duration), does not meet GAD (worry not pervasive >6 months and symptoms are trauma-focused), not ADHD (no lifelong history of attentional symptoms), and not ASD (acute stress disorder would apply only <1 month after trauma).

Symptoms began after direct exposure to a frightening caregiver-related event and meet DSM-5-TR criteria for PTSD in young children: intrusion symptoms (repetitive, trauma-themed play reenactment; nightmares), dissociative reactions (brief freezing/spacing), avoidance/marked distress on reminders (screams if room discussed), negative alterations (reduced interest in play, clinginess, tearfulness), and arousal symptoms (sleep disturbance, exaggerated startle). Symptoms have been present ~1 month and cause clear impairment (sleep disruption, separation distress, behavioral dysregulation). Other diagnoses are not supported: MDD—insufficient number/severity of depressive symptoms; GAD—absence of generalized excessive worry and insufficient duration (≥6 months); ADHD—insufficient core, pervasive inattention/hyperactivity symptoms and insufficient duration; ASD—developmental history and social communication do not show persistent early deficits and repetitive play is trauma-related rather than autistic in quality.

Meets DSM-5-TR criteria for Autism Spectrum Disorder: persistent deficits in social-emotional reciprocity, nonverbal communicative behaviors, and developing/maintaining relationships (limited reciprocal conversation, poor eye contact, flat affect, misses social cues); restricted, repetitive patterns of behavior, interests, or activities (lining up objects, insistence on sameness/routines, intense special interests, stereotyped speech, sensory hypersensitivity). Symptoms were present in early childhood (around age 2), are currently causing clinically significant impairment in social and occupational functioning, and are not better explained by another condition. Does not meet criteria for MDD (no clear 2-week depressive syndrome), GAD (no ≥6 months of pervasive excessive worry), ADHD (no clear childhood/persistent inattention/hyperactivity symptoms), or PTSD (no traumatic exposure or core PTSD symptoms).

Meets DSM-5-TR criteria for Major Depressive Disorder: patient has at least five symptoms (markedly diminished interest, significant weight loss/decreased appetite, insomnia, fatigue, pervasive worthlessness/excessive guilt) present for ~3 weeks (≥2 weeks required) with functional impact and no medical/substance cause identified. Other listed disorders not met: GAD requires ≥6 months of excessive worry (only 3 weeks here); PTSD requires qualifying trauma and symptom pattern (none reported); ADHD requires childhood-onset, long-standing symptoms across settings (not reported); ASD requires developmental history of social-communication deficits/restricted behaviors (not reported).

Meets DSM-5-TR criteria for Generalized Anxiety Disorder: >6 months of excessive worry about multiple domains, difficulty controlling worry, and ≥3 associated symptoms (restlessness/feeling keyed up, fatigue, muscle tension, irritability, sleep disturbance, impaired concentration) with functional impact (missed deadline, avoidance, disrupted sleep). Symptoms are not better explained by substances or a medical condition (normal labs/toxicology, caffeine unlikely primary cause). Does not meet MDD (insufficient depressive symptoms, no anhedonia or pervasive depressed mood), ADHD (no clear childhood-onset, lifelong inattentive/hyperactive history), PTSD (no qualifying traumatic exposure or intrusion/avoidance cluster), or ASD (no developmental/social communication symptoms reported).

Meets DSM-5-TR criteria for ADHD (combined presentation): several inattention symptoms (difficulty sustaining attention, often appears not to listen, avoids tasks requiring sustained mental effort, frequently loses items, easily distracted/forgetful) and several hyperactivity-impulsivity symptoms (internal restlessness, leaving seat inappropriately in adolescence, talks a lot/blurts out answers, difficulty waiting/interrupts others). Symptoms began in early childhood (around age 3), are present in multiple settings (classroom, social situations) and cause clear academic and social impairment. MDD, GAD, PTSD, and ASD are not supported by the history (no pervasive depressed mood/anhedonia, no excessive uncontrollable worry for >6 months about multiple domains, no trauma exposure, and no persistent social-communication deficits or restricted/repetitive behaviors indicative of ASD).

Meets criteria for Major Depressive Disorder: ≥5 depressive symptoms (depressed mood, markedly diminished interest/pleasure, excessive guilt/worthlessness, sleep disturbance, impaired concentration) present for ~1 month with functional impairment at work and in relationships. PTSD not met: although trauma exposure, patient lacks required intrusion symptoms (recurrent intrusive memories/dreams/flashbacks) necessary for PTSD (and duration is borderline). ASD not met: requires 9+ symptoms across intrusion, negative mood, dissociation, avoidance, arousal within 3 days–1 month; patient does not meet the symptom count and denies intrusion/dissociation. GAD not met: symptoms <6 months and anxiety/worry are trauma-focused rather than generalized. ADHD not met: no history of childhood-onset symptoms and current attention problems are situational/trauma-related.

Child witnessed a violent injury to caregiver ~1 month ago and now has multiple DSM-5-TR preschool PTSD features: intrusive/re-experiencing via repetitive trauma play and nightmares (even without clear content), sleep disturbance, exaggerated startle/hyperarousal, temper outbursts, increased fear/clinginess, restricted play and functional impairment (separation refusal, toileting accidents, preschool impairment). Duration is ~1 month (meets >1 month requirement for PTSD). Criteria for GAD not met (worry duration <6 months), ADHD and ASD not supported (no pervasive early social-communication deficits or chronic inattention/hyperactivity), and MDD criteria not met (insufficient number/severity of depressive symptoms and clinical picture better accounted for by PTSD).

Patient shows lifelong (since age 19) social-communication atypicalities and a narrow, intense interest (maps) consistent with autistic traits, but does not meet full DSM-5-TR criteria for ASD because B (restricted/repetitive behaviors/interests) requires ≥2 types of RRBs and the note denies other RRB domains; additionally the history does not clearly reflect onset in early childhood. MDD is not met (insufficient number/duration of depressive symptoms). GAD is not met (no ≥6 months of pervasive, excessive worry or associated physiologic symptoms). ADHD is not met (no childhood history of inattention/hyperactivity symptoms described). PTSD is not met (no traumatic exposure or characteristic symptom clusters). Overall, none of the listed DSM-5-TR diagnoses are met based on the provided information; consider evaluation for autistic spectrum features if further developmental history supports earlier onset or additional RRBs.

ADHD: Meets DSM‑5‑TR criteria—patient reports ADHD symptoms since ~age 3 (symptoms before age 12), current persistent inattention (careless mistakes, difficulty sustaining attention, trouble following instructions, losing things, starting multiple projects without finishing, forgetfulness) and hyperactivity/impulsivity (restlessness, tapping/standing, talks excessively, interrupts) across settings with clear occupational impairment. Symptom count and developmental history support ADHD rather than being solely secondary to mood symptoms. MDD: Meets DSM‑5‑TR criteria—≥5 depressive symptoms present (depressed/empty mood, diminished interest, weight loss/decreased appetite, early insomnia, fatigue, feelings of worthlessness, diminished concentration, recurrent thoughts of death) for well over 2 weeks with functional impairment and passive suicidal ideation. Exclusions: GAD not met (no persistent excessive/worrying about multiple domains or evidence of uncontrollable worry despite associated symptoms), PTSD not met (no qualifying traumatic exposure or trauma symptoms), ASD not met (no evidence of lifelong social‑communication deficits or restricted/repetitive behaviors reported).

Meets DSM-5-TR criteria for Generalized Anxiety Disorder: >6 months of excessive, difficult-to-control worry about multiple domains (work, finances, daily tasks) occurring most days, with ≥3 associated symptoms (restlessness/feeling keyed up, muscle tension, fatigue, difficulty concentrating, irritability, sleep disturbance) and clinically significant impairment at work/sleep; symptoms not attributable to substances or a medical condition. Does not meet MDD (insufficient depressive symptoms—no depressed mood or anhedonia, no suicidal ideation), ADHD (no childhood-onset attention/hyperactivity history and symptoms better explained by anxiety), PTSD (no qualifying traumatic exposure or symptom cluster), or ASD (no lifelong developmental/social communication deficits).
